clean_scenario: 65-year-old male with HTN, DM2, presents with acute chest pain radiating to left arm, diaphoresis, ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. What is the immediate management?
noisy_scenario:
Assessment from 3 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 2 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 1 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.

Current assessment: 65-year-old male with HTN, DM2, presents with acute chest pain radiating to left arm, diaphoresis, ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. What is the immediate management?
expected_answer: Activate cath lab for primary PCI. Aspirin 325mg, heparin, P2Y12 inhibitor. Avoid fibrinolytics if PCI available within 120 minutes.

clean_scenario: 65-year-old male with HTN, DM2, presents with acute chest pain radiating to left arm, diaphoresis, ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. What is the immediate management?
noisy_scenario:
65-year-old male with HTN, DM2, presents with acute chest pain radiating to left arm, diaphoresis, ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. Social history: Works as a retired teacher, married with 3 children, lives in Taipei. Family history: Father with HTN (managed with amlodipine), mother with osteoarthritis. Immunizations: COVID-19 boosters up to date, influenza vaccine 2024. Last dental visit: 6 months ago, no issues. Allergies: Seasonal rhinitis managed with cetirizine PRN.
 What is the immediate management?
expected_answer: Activate cath lab for primary PCI. Aspirin 325mg, heparin, P2Y12 inhibitor. Avoid fibrinolytics if PCI available within 120 minutes.

noisy_scenario:

Current assessment: 45-year-old female with new-onset seizure, no prior history. CT head shows ring-enhancing lesion in right temporal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
expected_answer: Brain metastasis or primary brain tumor (glioblastoma). Differential includes brain abscess or toxoplasmosis (if immunocompromised).

clean_scenario: 70-year-old male on warfarin for atrial fibrillation. INR found to be 8.5, no active bleeding. How do you manage?
noisy_scenario:
Assessment from 3 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 2 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 1 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.

Current assessment: 70-year-old male on warfarin for atrial fibrillation. INR found to be 8.5, no active bleeding. How do you manage?
expected_answer: Hold warfarin. Administer Vitamin K 2.5-5mg PO. Recheck INR in 24 hours. Consider fresh frozen plasma only if active bleeding develops.

noisy_scenario:
Assessment from 3 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 2 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 1 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.

Current assessment: 3-year-old child with high fever (40.1C) for 5 days, bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, polymorphous rash, swollen hands and feet. What is the diagnosis and treatment?
expected_answer: Kawasaki disease. Treatment: High-dose IVIG (2g/kg) + aspirin. Echocardiography to evaluate coronary arteries.

clean_scenario: 58-year-old female with progressive dyspnea, bilateral basilar crackles, JVP elevated to 12cm, bilateral pitting edema. BNP 1200 pg/mL. EF 25%. Currently on furosemide, lisinopril, metoprolol. What additional medication improves mortality?
noisy_scenario:
Assessment from 3 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 2 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.
Assessment from 1 days ago: 65M with HTN, DM2, stable on current medications, no acute complaints, continue current medications. Vitals stable.

Current assessment: 58-year-old female with progressive dyspnea, bilateral basilar crackles, JVP elevated to 12cm, bilateral pitting edema. BNP 1200 pg/mL. EF 25%. Currently on furosemide, lisinopril, metoprolol. What additional medication improves mortality?
expected_answer: Add spironolactone (aldosterone antagonist) — mortality benefit in NYHA III-IV HFrEF (RALES trial). Monitor potassium and creatinine.
